Given the Fourier transformed state at time T, \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(T,x)) \\), can we accurately reconstruct the initial state \\( u(0,x) \\) having known no interventions were applied?
Explanation: The Fourier transform in the context of the wave equation is reversible due to its properties under linear time-invariant systems. Given \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(T,x)) \\), we can apply the inverse Fourier transform and use the evolution laws of the wave components to reconstruct \\( u(0,x) \\) accurately.
